item.title: Huygens and $\pi$
item.description: arXiv:2412.10880v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: We present and ab initio detailed motivated presentation of Christian Huygens' geometric proofs of some of the most famous inequalities in circle quadrature. His monograph \emph{De circuli magnitudine inventa} is epoch-making for circular measurement and is, indisputably, one of the most beautiful and important elementary geometric treatises ever written. Yet, the literature does not offer the modern mathematician any detailed description of its rich content. Our paper fills this gap.
item.dc:creator: Mark B. Villarino

item.title: The Orientalists' Stance Towards Arabic Sciences (Especially Arabic Astronomy)
item.description: arXiv:2511.01664v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: In this paper, we highlight the influence of Arab/Islamic civilization in the field of the history of astronomy on European historians. We also aim to elucidate the stance of Orientalists toward the study of Arab sciences and to clarify their orientations, with a particular focus on astronomy, while revealing the significant role played by Arab scholars in this domain and the impact of their contributions-especially astronomical tables (zij)-on Western astronomers. Furthermore, we have clarified the mechanisms of transmission of Arab sciences, particularly astronomy, from Arab scholars to Western scholars, and the role of Arab astronomers in Western civilization. In addition, we address the contributions of Arab scholars to the development of astronomy and the perspective of Orientalists, particularly David King, regarding this matter. We also underscore the importance of Orientalists' works in analyzing Arab/Islamic scholarly output, identifying its influence on the West in the field of astronomy, and demonstrating how Western scholars benefited from translations of Arabic books in this discipline. In this paper, we adopt the historical retrieval methodology, by referencing previously documented astronomical information and contributions, with an emphasis on the processes of transmission of these sciences from the Arabs to the West.
item.dc:creator: Duaa Abdullah, Jasem Hamoud

item.title: The cycloid as brachistochrone: A one-page proof, from first principles, without calculus
item.description: arXiv:2507.22548v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Johann Bernoulli's optical solution of the brachistochrone problem is rebuilt on underlying (non-optical) principles. An "optical interpretation" is given afterwards.
item.dc:creator: Gavin R. Putland
